solution.text:
Total surface area \(= 6 \times 16^2 = 6 (side)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Length of side = \((\frac {1536}{6})^{\frac 12} = 16 cm\)

content.text: A closed box in the shape of a cube has a total outer surface area of 1536 \(cm^2.\) What is the length of its side in centimetres?

hint.text: Remember that surface area of a cube is \(6 \times side^2\)

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 132 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{132}{\pi} = 42 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 42\)
= 55.2 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(132 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

solution.text:
Area of tin sheet required for 1 box = Surface area of one box
\(= 2 (8 \times 6 + 6 \times 4 + 8 \times 4) = 208 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 6 boxes \(= 208 \times 6\)
\(= 1248 cm^2\)

content.text: You need to create a tin box of dimensions \(8 cm \times 6 cm \times 4 cm.\) What is the area of a sheet of tin required to make 6 such tins?

hint.text: Start by calculating the surface area of the box

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 12^2 \times 25 = 11314.29 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 11314.29 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 27 \times 20 \times h = 11314.29 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {11314.29}{27 \times 20} = 20.95\)
The new cuboid is 20.95 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 25 cm and radius 12 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 27 cm and breadth 20 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid?

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
The volume of the cylindrical pool \(= \pi \times (\frac d2)^2 \times (h) m^3 = \pi \times (\frac{18}2)^2 \times (1) m^3\)
\(= 254571.43\) L

content.text: Your school is building a cylindrical swimming pool with a diameter of 18 metres and a depth of 1 metres. How much water (in litres) will they require to completely fill the pool?

hint.text: Volume of a cylindrical container = \(\pi \times r^2 \times h\) and \(1m^3 = 1000L\)

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 134 \times 40 + \frac 12 \times 55\times(134 + 104)\)
\(= 11905 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 2 km/hr = 2000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 11905 \times 2000 = 23810000 m^3/hr\)
= 23810 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 23810\)
= 4000080 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 134 m, b = 104 m, c = 40 m and d= 95 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 2 km / hr. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

solution.text:
The surface area of the box \(= 2 (22 \times 17 + 17 \times 13 + 22 \times 13) = 1762 cm^2\)
Cost of painting the box = Rs. 2.6 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the box = \(1762 \times 2.6\)
= Rs. 4581.2

content.text: Latika needs to paint a rectangular box from the outside. The cost of painting the box is Rs. 2.6 per \(cm^2.\) If the dimensions of the box are \(22 cm \times 17 cm \times 13 cm\), what is the total cost of painting the box?

hint.text: Start by calculating the surface area

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 27 \times (17 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{1039.5}{13.5} - 17\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(1039.5 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 17 metres and the width of the field is 27 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river?

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 4275 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 19 \times 9 = 171 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 250000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(4275 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 19 cm and a height of 9 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile.

solution.text:
Area of Garden = Area of Plot - Area of the House
\(= ab - cd\)
\(= (4176 - 46(18)) m^2\)
\(=3348 m^2\)

content.text: Kshitij is looking to landscape his garden. He made a diagram of his house (grey colour) but forgot to mention the exact dimensions of the garden area. solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{26}2 \times 12 + 2 \pi \times \frac{5}2 \times 12 + 2\pi({\frac{26}2}^2 - {\frac{5}2}^2)\)
= 2192.14\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 2192.14 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 438.43

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 26 cm and an inner diameter of 5 cm. Its length is 12 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost of painting the pipe?

hint.text: Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims

\(= \frac 12 \times 30 \times 31 + \frac 12 \times 68.5 \times 46 + \frac 12 \times 37.5 \times 22.5 + \frac 12 \times 30 \times 37.5 + \frac 12 \times 61 \times 30\)

= 7307.14\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)

= 62841.43 g

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 2819.14 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (8)^2 \times 23 - \pi (8-x)^2 \times 23\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{23\pi}=8^2 - (8-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (8-x)^2 = 64 - \frac{V}{23\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 8 - 5\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The volume of a metallic cylinder pipe is 2819.14 cubic centimetres. Its length is 23 cm and its external radius is 8 cm. Find its thickness

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 7341.71 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {18}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {18}{2} - 5)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {18}2)^2-\pi (\frac {18}2 - m)^2}\)
= 35.94 cm

content.text: How many litres of water can a cubical tank of side 14 m hold?

hint.text: Volume of a cube = \(side^3\)

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 7392\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{7392}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{7392}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {7392\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 28 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 14 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 34496 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 7392 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text: Volume = Area of base \(\times\) height \(= 44 cm^2 \times 14 cm = 616 cm^3\)

content.text: The area of the base of a cylinder is \(44 cm^2\). Its height is 14 cm. What is the volume?
The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 936 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(936 m^2\)
Therefore, \(936 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{936}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{9}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 3 metres

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

Therefore, number of cubes that can be cut \(= \frac {26^3}{13^3} = 8\) cubes

Therefore, the volume will double

V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi (2r)^2h = 4\pi r^2h = 4V\)
Therefore, the volume will quadruple

V \(= \pi r^2h\)

Therefore, the volume will quarter

solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 2.3^2 = 158.7 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(2.3^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 158.7 - 52.9 = 105.8 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 7 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(105.8 \times 7\)
= Rs. 740.6

Area covered per rotation \(= 550 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 56 rolls \(= 550 \times 56 = 30800 cm^2\)
